Summary: The paper investigates the impact of various adaptive learning rate schedules on the performance of diffusion models, focusing on StepLR, CyclicLR, and CosineAnnealingLR. The authors provide a detailed experimental setup, rigorous evaluation metrics, and extensive results to highlight the strengths and weaknesses of each learning rate schedule. The study is conducted on simple 2D datasets to validate the findings.
Questions: ['Why were only simple 2D datasets used? Would the findings generalize to more complex datasets?', 'Have other hyperparameter optimization techniques been considered?', 'Can the authors provide more qualitative analysis and cases to support their findings?', 'Can the authors provide more theoretical insights into why certain learning rate schedules perform better than others?', 'How would the findings generalize to more complex datasets or higher-dimensional data?', 'What are the limitations of the current study, and how do the authors plan to address them in future work?']
Limitations: ['The primary limitation is the simplicity of the datasets used, which may not reflect real-world scenarios.', 'The study does not explore other hyperparameter optimization techniques beyond learning rate schedules.', 'The potential limitations and broader applicability of the findings are not adequately addressed.']
Strengths: ['The paper addresses a relevant topic in optimizing diffusion models.', 'The experimental setup and evaluation metrics are well-detailed.', 'The comparison of different learning rate schedules is systematic.']
Weaknesses: ['The study is conducted on relatively simple 2D datasets, which may not generalize to more complex datasets.', 'The paper lacks novelty and does not introduce new techniques or insights.', 'The findings may not be broadly applicable to other types of generative models or more complex data.', 'The potential limitations and broader applicability of the findings are not adequately addressed.']
